awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Biogeochemical Controls on the Dynamics of Organoarsenic Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Organoarsenic compounds are widespread in nature, occurring in freshwater and marine as well as terrestrial environments.  Organisms, including bacteria, fungi, algae, invertebrates, vertebrates and even humans, can biotransform arsenic (As), converting inorganic to organic As, and in some cases vice-versa, producing a range of structurally simple to complex organoarsenic compounds in the environment.  In addition to natural sources, organoarsenicals have been synthesized for agricultural, medicinal, and military uses.  The use of organoarsenicals in the poultry industry, for example, has increased dramatically as the industry has grown.  Roxarsone (3-nitro 4-hydroxybenzene arsonic acid) is added to poultry feed up to 45.5g per ton for the purpose of improving weight gain, feed efficiency, and pigmentation.  When roxarsone is removed from feed for a 5-d period before slaughter, As concentrations in tissue are below the USFDA limit of 0.5 mg/kg.  The majority (95%) of the As is excreted from the animal, resulting in elevated As (15 to 77 mg/kg) in poultry litter.  Because poultry litter is rich in nutrients, more than 90% of it is land-applied as fertilizer.  The disposal of poultry waste through land application results in release of an estimated 10^6kg of As to the environment.  Recent work has demonstrated that As in poultry litter is highly water soluble and thus potentially mobile.  Biotransformation of roxarsone and other organoarsenicals has been documented in the laboratory, but to date, there is little known about the ultimate fate of roxarsone, and other organoarsenicals, in watersheds.   

The goal of our proposed research is to examine the biogeochemical controls on organoarsenic transformation in a watershed within the Delmarva Peninsula, a region of intense poultry production.  Our main hypothesis is that organoarsenic transformation is carried out by diverse microbial populations under a range of biogeochemical conditions.  We will conduct intensive field monitoring of soil, ground, and surface waters before and after litter application to determine the concentration and form of As in each of these water types.  We will use biochemical and molecular techniques to identify and characterize microbial communities in the water samples and to examine the impact of biogeochemical conditions on microbial community structure.  To enhance public understanding of water quality, we will work with students, teacher, and community groups on water quality sampling projects on two river systems, one in a mostly forested and rural area (New River, Southwestern VA) and another impacted by agricultural and industrial land uses in an urban area (Allegheny, Monongahela, and Ohio Rivers, Pittsburgh, PA).

Trace elements, including an organic form of arsenic (As), are added to poultry feed as to provide micronutrients, control infection, and improve weight gain.  Due to low accumulation of these elements in poultry tissue, elevated concentrations of these elements are found in poultry litter. The overall research objective was to examine how trace elements, including As, copper (Cu), and zinc (Zn), are leached from poultry litter and the extent to which these elements are released to water in regions where poultry litter is widely used as fertilizer.

To address our objective, our research team conducted a series field and laboratory experiments, described below, using a field site on the Delmarva Peninsula, a region of intense poultry production. The field site had not received litter application for over six years, making it an ideal location for the experiments. The Virginia Tech team included an associate professor, one primary graduate student, and four undergraduates, as well an outreach
specialist.  Our team collaborated with two professors and a graduate student at Duquesne University, who were focused on biological transformation processes affecting As.

After instrumenting our field site and monitoring background geochemical characteristics of soil water, ground water, and surface water, we conducted a poultry litter application experiment.  After the application, we continued monitoring for a period of six months. Results showed release of low concentrations of trace elements and nutrients from litter into soil water. Little impact was measured on ground or surface water.  Mass balance calculations of trace elements in litter, soil water, and soil suggested that the majority of trace element mass released from litter was retained in the B soil horizon.  We followed up with a laboratory column experiment, using soil (B horizon) collected from the field site. The purpose was to examine the impact of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) on the mobility of litter-derived elements in the subsurface. Results showed that DOC mobilized Cu, Zn, As and P in litter leachate, but to varying degrees, which can be explained by different geochemical interactions of these elements with organic matter (both dissolved and solid) as well as minerals in soils.  To examine the impact of litter application on a broader scale, we collected sediment samples from streams in the Broadkill River watershed, also on the Delmarva Peninsula, and examined statistical relationships between trace element concentrations and land use. Statistically significant differences in trace element concentrations between reference sites (forested regions) and downgradient sites were measured.  Correlation analysis between sediment trace element enrichment values and 2006 land use/land cover (LULC) data did not show
any clear statistical significant relationship between agricultural areas and enrichment.
